titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Anne Harney

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2013-09-13T20:26-0400

did.abstract: Dorothy Wolfers Nelkins (1933-2003), sociologist and science policy educator, documented the often uneasy relationship between science and the public, as the author or co-author of 26 books and numerous published articles. Educated at Cornell, her research centered on both how science was viewed by the public and how it was presented in the media. After her career at Cornell (1963-89), she became a distinguished NYU Professor in the Dept. of Sociology and an affiliated Professor at the School of Law there (1990-2003). Nelkins wrote about disputes over genetically-modified organisms, public responses to genetic manipulation, the implications of industry-university relationships and artists’ responses to the genetic revolution. Some of her most significant works include Selling Science: How the Press Covers Science and Technology (1987); Dangerious Diagnostics: the Social Power of Biological Information (1989), The DNA Mystique: The Gene as a Cultural Icon (1995) and Body Bazaar: The Market for Human Tissue in the Biotechnology Age (2001).

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Sociologist Dorothy Nelkin specialized in the relationship between science and society.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Series I – Correspondence (.5 linear foot) Series II – Research/Subject materials (8 linear feet) Series III- Works by Nelkins (7 linear feet)- Series IV- Works by others (2 linear feet) –Series V Conferences and Committees (2 linear feet) – Series VI- Court cases (0.75 linear feet) – Series VII-Personal Series-(0 .25 linear feet)-Series VIII- Printed Material - cartoons. Clippings? Dot’s published works? Her library? –Series IX –Ephemera-(0.25 linear feet)-Non-textual formats: Series X – Photos (2 folders) – Series XI-Computer disks.

odd.head: Collection Overview
odd.p: Collection Overview: Correspondence Series I consists of Dorothy Nelkin’s correspondence with various colleagues and scholars over the course of her entire professional life, as well as correspondence with publishers and co-authors. Of particular interest is her correspondence with, of the Human Genome Project. There are four letters to _____from Nelkin and some of Nelkin’s responses. The bulk of the correspondence is incoming. Correspondence with Publishers: is comprised of Nelkin’s correspondence with the many publisherss he worked with in over __ years of writing. The chief correspondents are Lori Andrews...

Works By Series III consists of works by Dorothy Nelkin, related notes, and correspondence; reviews of individual works are also included. It contains complete book manuscripts, as well as journal and popular magazine articles. Much of the series is comprised of undated manuscripts of both published and unpublished articles, typewritten by Nelkin. Also included are course materials from classes she taught at Cornell and NYU. Book reviews written by Nelkin are included, . authored by Nelkin are also included, which highlight the diversity of her interests and abilities. Speaking engagements/Lectures/Lectures notes [COURSE MATERIALS?????] Cornell/NYU:

Series V is made up of material from Nelkins work while at Cornell and NYU. Nelkin served many years as a professor/lecturer and later as a Visiting Scholar at…. The series consists of class materials, student evaluations, and correspondence to and from the University, ….

Series VI is comprised of works by others, and greatly reflects Nelkin’s varied research interests: racial and social equality, women’s rights, child development, humanistic psychology and genetics. Such interests are represented by the works of many influential people in the aforementioned fields, such as ______and many others. Although Nelkin remained well read in the works of those authors she did not always agree with, especially the racial and eugenic theories of authors such as ____. So while the series does not accurately reflect the entirety of Nelkin’s opinions, it is a great resource for discovering the topics she returned to again and again. Topics of interest. DNA; obtaining unauthorized tissue samples/treatment of bodies….cord blood, animal rights/cloning; science of race; law and cloning; surveillance (data storing microchips) Includes a number of reviews of works by Nelkin by other authors.

Committees and Organizations Series VII consists of material relating to the various committees and organizations in which Nelkin participated. From ___ to ___, Nelkin AAAS Committee on Scientific Freedom and Responsibility, serving as chair of its Subcommittee on Intellectual Property…..served on the AAAS Board of Directors, 1983-7….as the chairperson and consequently much of this series consists of material….AAAS committee on Science, Technology and Public Policy, Also [prevalent] represented is material relating to the American Bar Association, NYU Institute for the Humanities; NY Bar Association, Committee on Bioethical Issues. a number of ____ and _____groups.

Certificates and awards Series VIII contains certificates and awards received by Ashley Montagu. A majority of the series dates to the 1990s, and is largely made up of lifetime achievement awards. Personal Information: Series IX, the Personal Information series is composed of several versions of Nelkin’s curriculum vitae, a letter of appointment? This series also includes a Xerox of her _____ passport, personal financial documents, among other ephemera. Certificate???

Printed Materials Series X, the printed materials series, consists of published works and reprints authored mainly by others, but includes many works by herself. Also included are bound volumes, magazines and newsletters, as well as trial transcripts from the_______ case, for which Nelkin was deposed.

Photographs Series XI consists of photographs. Two folders; Folder 1 includes photos for her mss. Of Workers at Risk: Voices from the Workplace. (1984). Folder 2 includes a portrait of Dorothy for use in publications and a personal candid? photo of Nelkin and ______ Series XI also contains photos removed from correspondence for conservation purposes,
Computer disks Series XI consists of versions of her published works, including Body Bazaar and The Business of Bodies, as well as several unlabelled disks.

bibliography.head: Bibliography-Selected publications
bibliography.p: On the Season: Aspects of the Migrant Labor System (1970). New York State School of Industrial and Labor Relations, Cornell University. The University and Military Research: Moral Politics at MIT (1972). Cornell University Press. Jetport: The Boston Airport Controversy (1975). Transaction Books 1977a. Technological Decisions and Democracy. Beverly Hills, Calif.: Sage. 1977b. "Technology and Public Policy." In Science, Technology and Society: A Cross-Disciplinary Perspective, ed. I. Spiegel-Rosing and D. de Solla Price, pp. 393-442. London: Sage. 1979 Controversy: Politics of Technical Decisions. Beverly Hills: Sage. Science Textbook Controversies and the Politics of Equal Time (1977). MIT Press. The Atom Besieged: Extra-Parliamentary Dissent in France and Germany (with Michael Pollak; 1981). MIT Press. The Creation Controversy: Science or Scripture in the Schools (1982). New York: W.W. Norton. Science as Intellectual Property, 1983. Workers at Risk: Voices from the workplace (with M.S. Brown; 1984). Chicago: University of Chicago Press. The Language of Risk: Conflicting Perspectives in Occupational Health (1985). SAGE Publications. Selling Science: How the press covers science and technology (1987). W.H., Freeman Press. Translated into Japanese and Spanish. 2nd ed., 1995. Dangerous Diagnostics: The Social Power of Biological Information (1989). New York: Basic. 2nd ed. 1994. A Disease of Society: The Cultural Response to AIDS (with D. Willis, eds.; 1991). Cambridge U. Press. The Animal Rights Crusade, 1991. Controversy: Politics of Technical Decision, 3d ed., 1992. The DNA Mystique: The Gene as Cultural Icon, 1995. The Body Bazaar: The Market for Human (or Body?) Tissue in the Biotechnology (2001). Age Crown Books. Translated into Korean, Chinese, Japanese, and Italian. The Molecular Gaze (with Suzanne Anker; 2003). Cold Spring Harbor Press. http://depts.washington.edu/hssexec/newsletter/1997/nelkin.html (Science, Technology and Public Policy)
